Posts.Content: My suggestion is to buy Dr. Myer's new book on diest and prostate cancer. He is a former NIH researcher, had PCa himself, and now devotes himself to PCa patients. He has some definite advice on both diet and supplements. Search for Dr. Snuffy Myers, he is based in VA. I think you'll be impressed with the discernment he uses to make sense of all the info that's out there re PCa. He has the background and training to sift thru the many studies and determine which are valid and have an impact on PCa. Best wishes!

Posts.Title: Diet

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hawk I am not sure if this has been discussed here since I have been away from the forum for some time but I found this article by a Harvard Urologist and the acceptance of his writings by the New England Journal of Medicine to be extremely interesting. It is a little long because it is thorough. It addresses testosterone replacement therapy and the perceived threat Testosterone flare and low testosterone as being a risk factor for prostate cancer http://www.lef.org/magazine/mag2008/...pplements-menu I bought Dr. Morgentaler's book- it is fascinating, and goes totally against what I had been told. I am now trying to get my testosterone level up with some natural supplements.

Posts.Title: Testosterone's Effect on Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: My story sounds very similar to your husband's. I was 58 and had robotic scheduled, but some of the stories I read here, and experiences of some of my friends, had me scared. My PCa was a 3+4, PSA 6.3. At the last minute, I heard about and quickly became up to speed with HIFU. It is approved everywhere in the world, I believe, except the US, and third stage trials are going on now. I had the left side "cooked" or ablated. Catheter was out in four days, with absolutely no negative effect on urinary or sexual performance. I'll be glad to talk with your husband or you, if you do send a private message to me on this site and we'll set a time. Best wishes whatever your decision!

Posts.Content: I know I sound like a broken record, but I recommend everyone diagnosed with PCa to visit Dr. Charles Myers' website and watch the appropriate videos there. And, if you can afford to schedule a visit at his clinic ($1600-2500 I was told, no insurance), do so. In my opinion, formed from reading his newsletters and watching his videos myself, there is no one I would trust more than him to find a cure or slow the progression as much as possible. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Husband just diagnosed with Advanced PC

Posts.Content: Here's another option: HIFU. I had surgery scheduled but once I read about HIFU, I cancelled. I had PCa only on one side, and chose to have only that side ablated. Recovery was quick with essentially zero urinary or sexual issues. Also there is some good info out there about diet and supplements as related to prostate cancer. I was able to drive my PSA from 6.3 to 1.8 or so with diet and supplements only. The guru, in my opinion, is Charles Myers in Charlottesville, VA. He is a former cancer researcher, MD, had PCa himself, now devotes himself solely to men with PCa. He has a lot of good info on his web site and a new book on diet. Better yet, go see him if you can afford it- he doesn't take insurance. Educate yourself, and choose what fits you best. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Here's my two cents worth: I have done a lot of reading over the past 18 months, and I have come to believe there is no one better equipped to shut down prostate cancer than Dr. Charles Myers in Charlottesville, VA. He is a former cancer drug researcher and had PCa himself. He understands how the drugs work and interact and believes that supplements can help as well. Unfortunately he does not take insurance, so the cost will probably be higher than a doctor who does. Best wishes for a long, healthy life!

Posts.Title: My Story

Posts.Content: I went thru the same mental anguish as you in trying to decide which treatment would be best. Surveys show that doctors will overwhelmingly recommend what they do, ie, surgeons will normally recommend surgery. So, you have to decide what is best for you. I had surgery scheduled, but cancelled after hearing and learning about HIFU. Side effects were very minimal, and I am following Dr. Charles Myers' advice on diet and supplements in great hope of minimizing recurrence in the half of my prostate that was not ablated. Diet and supplements really drove my PSA down before my treatment so I feel they are having a significant impact. Only time will tell, but if my PSA stays stable, I will know I made the right choice. If it returns, I'll probably have to look at radiation. At this short period after treatment, I'm delighted with my decision. Best wishes for wisdom and peace in your decision making process.

I would also recommend educating yourself as much as possible, although like you there is so much info out there it is very confusing. I subscribed to Myers' newsletters, and find them very informative and gave me a greater appreciation for his work in his PCa clinic. He is a MD, retired NIH cancer researcher, and had PCa himself. Smart, inquisitive guy who appears to have a lot of common sense and wisdom. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Introduction

Posts.Content: If your husband has a Gleason 6, most urologists agree it should be watched, not removed. However, if one/both of you can't live peacefully with the thought of harboring cancer, then have it removed. When I considered the potential of incontinence, impotence, and penile shortening, I decided to cancel my surgery and went a different route. Everyone is different. I decided to eliminate the cancer that was large enough to be detectable by MRI (confirmed by biopsy), and try to keep the remainder of my prostate healthy and avoid any potential side effects. With all the new drugs and technologies on the way, I was willing to guarantee my quality of life in exchange for a higher risk of recurrence. To each his own.

Posts.Title: Dad has PC .

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Booo G) Gleason 3+3 was 10% in the first report. I think they sent everything they had. They sent 38 slides. 3 of each but 4 of G & H. The first pathologist also stained G & H so they may be why there was an extra slide of those. Not sure about a 3rd opinion because I too think it would be hard to beat Hopkins. And we also had to pay on our own for the Hopkins because the Dr would not fill out the paper work..said it was not needed (the paper work ) Looking for a new Dr. I am hoping to is good news for husband and not just another biopsy...but ya got to be sure about this stuff. For a Gleason 6, buy your husband Dr. Charles Myers' latest book on diet for PCa. Go to his website and watch his videos on Gleason 6's and learn about the lifestyle changes and supplements he recommends. He has a PCa growth arrest program that has worked so far for me- it dropped my PSA from 6.3 to 2.0 in a few months.

Posts.Title: Got 2nd opinion from John Hopkins

Posts.Content: There are so many side effects from having a prostate procedure that I would encourage you to do what you can to preserve a healthy prostate. I have become a follower of Dr. Charles Myers, himself a prostate cancer survivor, and now operates a clinic for men with PCa. Read his bio at this website. You can also subscribe to his newsletter, and even apply to be admitted as a patient if you want to travel to VA. As a former cancer researcher, he is able to sift thru studies that look at different supplements and even has an opinion on Avodart as a means of helping to prevent prostate cancer. Best wishes for a long, cancer-free life! Originally Posted by RobO I am 33 years old, and I was diagnosed with BPH at age 26. There is family medical history on my mother's side of prostate cancer, which ultimately killed her father (age 71) and brother (age 50). Additionally, I have done genetic screening through the website 23andMe.com, and there is states I have a 11.2% higher risk of developing prostate cancer between the ages of 35 - 79 than the average male population. Basically, I have begun to look at prostate cancer as a mater of 'when', not 'if.' I have had my PSA levels tested 3 times in the last 3 years, with a rise of only 1 point (last level was 1.3); however, I do not have complete faith in PSA screening. I've read recent articles on the validity of PSA testing, showing they may not be as useful as once thought. I've talked with my doctor about these studies, and he agrees with them, but suggests that I continue screening because, "at least it's something." My concern (and his as well) is that once someone shows outward signs and symptoms of prostate cancer it may have already began to spread to other parts of the body, decreasing survival rates. The alternative is periodic invasive biopsies, which I fear insurance companies will not support unless there is due cause. My question: Is there such a thing as preemptive prostate removal? I completely understand the risks of incontinence and impotence associated with this major surgery and do not take this lightly, but these concerns are not nearly as important to me as living a longer life. Knowing my chances of developing cancer, I feel like I'm playing with fire and, statistically speaking, I will eventually get burned. If I addressed my concerns to a doctor and laid out my case, would preemptive removal be something I could get a doctor to consider? Thanks for reading.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Posted by RobO I am 33 years old  and I was
ultimately killed her father  age 71  and brother  age 50 <Z>

Posts.Signature: 58 years old PSA 6.3 at peak 10/2011 PSA 2.0 after diet changes and supplements 1/2012 PSA 1.4 after diet changes and supplements and Avodart 6/2012 5/21/2012 12 needle biopsy Gleason 3+4 Left apex 15% of tissue Left base lat 10% of tissue Left mid small focus atypical T1c HIFU hemi-ablation on 8/24/2012 with no urinary, bowel, or sexual side effect
Posts.Title: Preemptive Prostate Removal?

Posts.Content: I am of the opinion that you can in fact put the brakes on pca development, or at least slow progression considerably. Watch these short video clips to get some idea of the things Dr. Myers is doing to slow pca: http://askdrmyers.wordpress.com/2011...r-supplements/ High Dose Vitamin D? http://askdrmyers.wordpress.com/2010...n-d-dangerous/ Supplements to avoid? http://askdrmyers.wordpress.com/2010...-should-avoid/ You can see from my short pca history that my PSA went down considerably after changing diet and taking Myers' recommended supplements. I would not do anything with a 3+3 except keep the psa monitored. I don't know that you can completely cure pca with diet and supplements, but you can live forever with a 3+3. Also read about metformin in the Life Extension website, Livestrong, and others; and read about Avodart as a preventative. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Biopsy Negative

Posts.Content: I'll let someone else interpret your PSA score, I don't feel competent enough given your completion of two procedures. I just wanted to encourage you to educate yourself so that you can make the best future decisions for you. I am an unabashed fan of Dr. Charles Myers, although I do not go to his PCa-only clinic. He has a new book on diet and PCa, regularly produces short videos on different PCa topics available on his website, and publishes a subscription newsletter (which I subscribe to). Looking at my PSA history shows what diet and supplements did for me, but everyone is different, and others may not have the same results as I. Here is a sampling of some videos Dr. Myers has made, many more are accessible on his website: Super supplements? http://askdrmyers.wordpress.com/2011...r-supplements/ High Dose Vitamin D? http://askdrmyers.wordpress.com/2010...n-d-dangerous/ Supplements to avoid? http://askdrmyers.wordpress.com/2010...-should-avoid/ Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: Rising PSA?

Posts.Content: Have your friend check out Dr. Charles Myers' website. He is a doctor and PCa survivor, and now operates a clinic for PCa. You can also find videos there and subscribe to his newsletters. He is a former cancer researcher and for my money, offers the most unbiased, cutting edge info I found after being diagnosed. You can never have too much info, although it can be very confusing to sort thru it. Good luck. Originally Posted by woodrow585 This is my first time on the site and I didn't really know where else to go. One of my best friends told me like a week ago that her dad was diagnosed with prostate cancer. Yesterday she told me that it has spread to his bones and it only took one year, which I guess is rare because it usually takes 5 years for that to happen. She is a doctor by the way. I would give the world for her and I am a very empathetic person so this has hit me also. I have begun to research things about it and seeing how she is a doctor she uses a lot of words I don't know what they are. I am trying to learn more about it so I can continue to be there for her without her having to explain everything to me. I know that the cancer has metastisized and he hasopted to take the drugs and not do the castration. I really just need to get educated and learn what's the best way to be there for my friend. I know this will be one of the worst things she will ever have to go through and neither one of us really believe in god so I want to be there for her. What are some of the treatments and what will the meds do to him? How do I respond when she talks to me about her dad not being there anymore? what are some nice things I can do? I know I will still invite her to things and treat her like my friend but there is no ignoring what's going on. What are some do's and don't's? Any help that anyone can give me would be great and I appreciate it. Adam
Posts.Signature: 58 years old PSA 6.3 at peak 10/2011 PSA 2.0 after diet changes and supplements 1/2012 PSA 1.4 after diet changes and supplements and Avodart 6/2012 5/21/2012 12 needle biopsy Gleason 3+4 Left apex 15% of tissue Left base lat 10% of tissue Left mid small focus atypical T1c HIFU hemi-ablation on 8/24/2012 with no urinary, bowel, or sexual side effect
Posts.Title: I need some help

Posts.Content: Buy Dr. Charles Myers' newest book on diet and prostate cancer. Also he has a website with info on supplements. Check out his bio; he is a former cancer researcher, and only recommends what he finds to be proven in studies. He also had PCa himself. Being on his diet and supplements caused my PSA to crash before I had HIFU. It didn't cure the cancer, obviously, but from the PSA results, really slowed it down. If you can afford to see him (he doesn't take insurance) talk to his office about an appt. Best wishes for 2013.
Posts.Signature: 58 years old PSA 6.3 at peak 10/2011 PSA 2.0 after diet changes and supplements 1/2012 PSA 1.4 after diet changes and supplements and Avodart 6/2012 5/21/2012 12 needle biopsy Gleason 3+4 Left apex 15% of tissue Left base lat 10% of tissue Left mid small focus atypical T1c HIFU hemi-ablation on 8/24/2012 with no urinary, bowel, or sexual side effect
Posts.Title: Diet or supplement recommendations to aid treatment plan? ebrt/seeds/adt

Posts.Content: My best advice is to read all you can on Dr. Charles Myers website- he has a lot of short videos on many PCa issues. You can also subscribe to his newsletters for a nominal cost, or order back issues of interest. I spent hours on the internet trying to learn more when I was first diagnosed, and have come to regard him as the best, most objective advice out there. He is a former Natl Inst of Health researcher and had PCa himself. His clinic only handles PCa patients, I believe. If you can afford to see him, new patient cost is $1500-2500, I have been told. He seems to be especially knowledgable around advanced PCa cases. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: Get yourself up to speed on diet and PCa, a good book is Dr. Charles Myers' newest on the topic. Hopefully eating healthy and exercise will help keep the robot away.

Posts.Title: Welcome me to the club!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jerseyguy Dave, Since you are considered low risk, take your time and do as much research as possible. When I was diagnosed two years ago my Dr. wanted me to decide on a treatment in a week. I decided on radiation (IMRT). Luckily I changed my mind last minute and boy am I glad. Over the last 2 years I have monitored my PSA and had two MRI's. Just this week I had a MRI guided biopsy which takes a biopsy sample from the suspicious tumor. This increases the accuracy of the biopsy, no guessing if they missed a higher grade cancer. I bring this up to point out you have to be your own advocate and educate yourself. I agree 100%. Many doctors want to do to you what they are good at, surgery or radiation. And they don't make money by keeping you healthy and away from their favorite procedure. Educate yourself, the longer you can avoid having to act on possible PCa, the longer you can avoid the side effects.
Posts.Signature: 58 years old PSA 6.3 at peak 10/2011 PSA 2.0 after diet changes and supplements 1/2012 PSA 1.4 after diet changes and supplements and Avodart 6/2012 5/21/2012 12 needle biopsy Gleason 3+4 Left apex 15% of tissue Left base lat 10% of tissue Left mid small focus atypical T1c HIFU hemi-ablation on 8/24/2012 with no urinary, bowel, or sexual side effect
Posts.Title: Welcome me to the club!

Posts.Content: I also had surgery scheduled, but was scared of the side effects. After hearing about HIFU and reading about it, I chose that route and have had no side effects. I also decided to change my diet, exercise more, and take supplements that I had good confidence in, ones that were recommended by doctors I trusted. MRI is more definitive for diagnosing PCa than ultrasound if that helps. My recommendation is to adopt the diet as outlined in Dr. Myers newer (just out) book on diet and PCa, exercise, take doctor-recommended supplements you have confidence in from reading, and thoroughly educate yourself before making a decision that you will live with forever- there are several posts here from men who are miserable after treatments because of the side effects. Visit Dr. Charles Myers website and watch some of this videos on PCa. Best wishes!

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Let me say a couple of things also: I briefly considered surgery, but also kept finding red flags, such as ED, incontinence, penile shortening. Do doctors who do HIFU push more HIFU than surgeons push surgery? Probably not. And surgeons have close financial ties to surgery- that's how they make a lot of their money. To each his own.

Posts.Title: HIFU stats?

Posts.Content: A heads up for those with advanced cancer; check out the recent news articles about driving copper levels to 20% of normal. The first patients that this was tried on apparently apparently had their cancer growth stopped, with no side effects. Just a thought for those who are searching for ways to keep scratching and clawing.

Posts.Title: A Positive Note for the Newly Diagnosed -- Part 1 of 2

Posts.Content: Don't panic, just do lots of reading to educate yourself so you can make the best decision possible for you two. Here is reading I would recommend: buy Dr. Charles Myers' NEW book on diet and PCa. And visit his website. He has a PCa clinic in VA, is a former medical researcher, and PCs survivor himself. You can watch videos free at his site, and he offers a newsletter you can subscribe to or buy back issues of. My opinion is he has the most unbiased info out there on PCa, and has some definite opinions on what can help and what won't. I did hours of reading, and after finding his website, pretty much decided he is the source of what I do to keep the remaining half of my prostate healthy. Take a deep breath, and concentrate on becoming a PCa expert. Remember that doctors will usually recommend what they are familiar with- if they do RP, they will recommend RP. If they do seed, they will often recommend seeds. A recent study I saw found that, it wasn't an original idea of mine. Here is a quote from his book: "There is a natural tendancy for all of us to blindly accept a doctor's advice. The idea is that you have put yourself in the hands of a highly competent professional whom you trust to make appropriate decisions about your health. This is not a good idea. There are many options....no one physician is an expert in the full range of possibilities. There is also a real tendancy for physicians to favor the particular approach they use; they are proud of their skills." Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Help newbie need advice

Posts.Content: An excellent book on testosterone is "Testosterone for Life" by Morgantaler. Also, a heart healthy diet and exercise is also prostate healthy. Also buy Dr. Charles Myers new book on diet and PCa. Good luck.

Posts.Title: 5.6 psa-

Posts.Content: I have done much reading the past two years, and I have come to regard Dr. Charles Myers as the one doctor who can best preserve life. He has a short list of supplements that he feels are helpful. Perhaps you can't afford to travel here, but you could buy some of the past issues of his newsletter and glean some info from them. Google "copper and cancer" and look at a recent, early study on dropping blood copper levels and arresting cancer growth. The study showed no side effects, so there's probably nothing to lose. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: As someone else has already stated, AS is an option. Stats show no difference in mortality between AS and surgery for a 3+3. I personally was willing to live with 3+3, but when the 3+4 biopsy came, I had to do something. In the meantime, I spent many hours on the internet trying to sort out what might be effective in slowing the PCa growth. I have put my faith in Dr. Charles Myers newest book on diet and PCa, and take the supplements he recommends on his website as well as Avodart. As you can tell from my bio, diet and supplements (no Avodart) made my PSA really drop before I had HIFU. You can visit his website and watch the apropriate video clips. Everyone has to make the decision that is right for them- I was willing to have a less aggressive procedure and modify my diet, in addition to taking several supplements, instead of risking sexual and urinary side effects. Only time will tell if I made the best decision, but I made the one that was right for me at the time. Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: HIFU stats?

Posts.Content: I have become a big fan of Dr. Charles Myers- retired cancer researcher, MD, had prostate cancer himself, now has a PCa-only clinic in VA. Visit his website and buy his newest book on nutrition, "The New Prostate Cancer Nutrition Book". Unfortunately he does not discuss supplements in the book. I subscribed to his newsletter after I was diagnosed last spring, and have found them to be very informative. His practice does not take insurance, so if you can afford a visit there, and want what I consider to be the most well-rounded information available, contact his office. I have read that 80% of his patients fly in- that should give some insight into his wisdom. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Reading List.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oatmealnut A friend had a test in July when his PSA went from 2 a couple of years ago to 10. He cleaned out his diet and started on a regiment of herbs and this week his PSA results are 6.38. Any ideas as to what this could mean? He is considering to have a biopsy. Can anyone suggest a good doctor in Charlotte NC or Duke University area? Or Atlanta, GA? Thank you After I changed my diet and started taking a few supplements recommended by Dr. Charles Myers, my PSA went down more than that, %_wise. I don't think the combination can cure prostate cancer but I believe being healthy and taking some carefully selected supplements can slow progression. Dr. Myers has an impressive resume, has gone thru prostate cancer himself, and the only patients he sees are prostate cancer patients. He has posted a LOT of info on his website.
